description: Borrowed from French effleurage, from effleurer (“to stroke lightly”).

entries.meaning: (massage) A form of massage involving smooth strokes of the skin with one's hands.
examples: Starting at the point of shoulder, use muscle squeezings, picking-ups, kneadings and gentle frictions, interspersed with effleurages, over the triceps muscle as well as the fleshy part of the flexor and extensor muscle groups.

verbs.description: effleurage (third-person singular simple present effleurages, present participle effleuraging, simple past and past participle effleuraged)

entries.meaning: (massage) To gently stroke the skin in a circular motion with the palm of one's hands.
